NATURE_DOC: ^So here we are, in the heart of the Great Morning Jungle.
^If you listen closely you can hear the bird songs. Notice how they repeat and loop. Notice the artificial quality to the melodies. It's beautiful. A dawn chorus for the end of the natural world.

c: ^Dripping with grease from the frying pan, cooking up some eggs, bacon, sausages, hash browns. All scratchy and yellow, flipping the food, getting an even colour on all sides, cooked through and charred with that breakfast crust.
^The Long Goodbreakfast Lark eats worms, little six-legged insects, and sometimes tiny people.
^In a perpetual state of just waking up, the Long Goodbreakfast Lark's feathers don't ever rest in one position. They always have bed hair.
^This means that every Lark is unique, different. Because of this, the Long Goodbreakfast Lark is the only non-human creature to be shallow and picky in choosing a partner.

^Look at this little one, for example, they are lonely. No one has picked them. Their feathers are disgusting. They can't even bring themselves to look in the mirror. They make themself sick. Disgusting. Who would ever want to be with them?
^It sings like an alarm clock. Screeching and wailing, scary, familiar. It makes you rub the sand away from your eyes. It makes you reach for a cigarette.
^Now it sings like spring. Beautiful rising and falling flutes and strings. Another bird joins in, responding, elaborating.
^You pull out from your pocket a...
^The birds hush down to listen to what you are bringing to the chorus. They don't seem to enjoy it. There's something fake, something unnatural, about the way you play.
^Maybe best to leave it to the birds.
^The birds hush down to listen to what you are bringing to the chorus. They don't seem to enjoy it. There's something fake, something unnatural, about the way you play.
^Maybe best to leave it to the birds.
^The birds hush down to listen to what you are bringing to the chorus. They don't seem to enjoy it. There's something fake, something unnatural, about the way you play.
^Maybe best to leave it to the birds.
^You notice the song changing once more. It sounds aggressive? As if the birds are arguing... shouting at each other.

^Get the fuck out of my face you piece of shit. You don't know my situation. You don't know how I'm feeling. You're making me feel shit about something I already feel shit about every day. I don't ever want to talk to you again.
^The song dies away and you are returned to the ambience of the jungle.
^The colours on the Sunrise Solar Starflower are in a constant state of flux. They shift between gradients and hues like the rising sun in the Brownie Cove sky.
^This unpredictable effect attracts all kinds of wildlife to the flower, really buzzing with that hope of some sweet sweet pollination.
^They will be disappointed, unfortunately. The Sunrise Solar Starflower has no pollen. It has nothing for them but sadness.

^The Sunrise Solar Starflower has to grow very tall and very quickly in order to compete for light. The other plants in the jungle are much tougher, more confident in themselves, they'll do all they can to block ways for the Starflower to survive.

^The quicker the Starflower grows, the better, but unfortunately, it also means it is less stable. The Starflower collapses under stress, has regular migraines, unhappy and unhealthy relationships, a terrible work ethic. A tower fit to be trampled.
^They make great meals for the more energetic morning creatures in the jungle.
^The Sunrise Solar Starflower has, beneath its petals, a bud filled with highly concentrated hydrochloric acid.
^When insects are attracted to the plant, they slip into the bud and are instantly killed. The acid is strong enough to even kill some birds, as you can see over here.
^The flower then dissolves the organism in the acid, and empties the remains onto the ground. It doesnt use these organisms for nutrition, it's just a dick.
^Wiry, messy, too long. Needs a haircut.
^The hair is thick and grows all over the spider's body and legs. It gives the impression that the spider is more confident than it really is.
^The hairs can be used as a defense mechanism, the spider can obsessively fiddle with and rearrange the way the hair is falling on its forehead, as an effort to seem cool and collected.
^Look at the way they dart around, unable to settle on anything.

^It is a blind dinner date and the Caffeinated Weasel Spider cannot make eye contact with their date. They order the cheapest vegeterian dish, in an effort to look cool. Their date asks them about what they do, but the spider swallows their words and can't answer.
^The eyes are twitching, looking around for danger, looking for food, pumped up on coffee. The spider scuttles back into its den.
^Let's listen closely and see if we can make out what it is saying:

g-2: ^Just some stupid bug, who can tell what it's talking about.

g-0: ^I've never cared much for spiders. Too gross, too unpredictable.
^I remember once, at my old apartment...

c: ^Three or four of them in a little glass box. I can't remember the names. Huntsman spiders? Was that the species?

^They used to eat flies and crickets and other small insects that my roommate would buy in bulk. At the start of every season the freezer would get filled up with bags of dead insects. No room for any food.
^When I went away on holiday for a week and the flat was unoccupied I accidently turned off the freezer at the wall, and when I returned all of the insects had defrosted.
^Rotting and sitting in puddles of still water.

^The spiders were starving and had begun to eat each other. Only one remained, it had grown considerably larger, having eaten its friends. My flatmate wasn't even sure which one it was. The name had been forgotten.
^I think it was when we left the flat over the summer? There was a dead mouse rotting behind one of the kitchen cabinets.
^You know the way the food chain works. The rotting mouse breeds maggots, maggots become flies, spiders eat the flies. And by the time we returned the whole flat was swarming with them.
^We would go to the bathroom in the night and feel spiders running across our feet. They would crawl up the walls and across the ceilings.
^When we would try to go to sleep we would see shifts in light and colour across all the surfaces and hear their crawling, like distant rain, all through the night.

g-0: ^I had a spider nest under my bed.

c: ^A little white egg sack, dusty and fragile... like a clump of rotting used bandages.
^It had been there as long as I could remember, since I'd moved in at least. I never wanted to touch it and assumed it was dormant and therefore safe to have around.
^One night though, when I was having a bit of a manic episode I decided to move all the furniture in my room around and accidently knocked the egg sack.
^It burst open and thousands of baby spiders ran out and scattered around the room.

OUT_OF_OPTIONS: ^Well that's all for now, thank you for joining us. We hope you all have a beautiful morning.

COOKING_SHOW: ^Hello and welcome to Shrimp Heaven Now, your first stop for some of that good good seafood cooking. I'm so glad you could join us.

c: ^The most exciting, experimental, subversive shrimp meal of them all. I'm just... oh gosh, friends, I'm so excited to be cooking this with you today. I hope you're all sitting comfortably.
^The classic! The one and only. This is a recipe I learnt from my time working at Stinky Croc's Italian, and well, it's lasted me a good long time.
^Slurpy slimy shrimp sauce in a bowl. What more could you possibly want??

g-0: ^Turn that volume up, get your pan oiled, and lets get shrimping.
^First up, of course, we need the shrimp. So let's just catch that little scoundrel right now.

c: ^It is dripping with water, writhing around and squirming in your hands. It reminds you of a time when you happier, but you're not quite sure why. You throw it into the pot.
^You lower a net into the water and wait for a few minutes until you feel a tug. You retrieve it. Inside is a shrimp, a nice big one! You scoop it out and throw it into the pot.

^You think about the shrimp's family, the shrimp's friends, the shrimp's hopes and aspirations, and you decide not to catch it today. You instead knock up a seaweed and soy vegan alternative and throw it into the pan.

b: ^Then just add some spaghetti, some olive oil, give it a stir, and then you go!
^And then, for the big surprise... just wrap it up in mystery infinity paper, and pop it in the oven. You'll never know what comes out.
^Then just add some water and some vegetable stock and leave it to simmer for 2-3 hours.

g-5: ^I hope you enjoyed cooking with us today on Shrimp Heaven Now, please write in to us to let us know how you did... And join us next time for more shrimpy gooodness!

CALL_IN_SHOW: ^Hello out there, to all you lonely souls... You lost pilgrims, you quiet performers, you imprisoned drifters.
^Welcome to CHAT 4 U, the number one chat service in all of Brownie Cove.
^Would you like to chat to somebody else in a position like you? Just call the number you see on screen and we will connect you.

c: ^The phone on the TV rings, someone picks up and answers.
^I'm sorry to hear that. Is there anything I can do to help?
^The phone on the TV rings, someone picks up and answers.

NEWS: ^This is Brownie Cove News, coming at you LIVE from the tip top of the tallest tower. You know the one. That tall tower.
^We have a whole bunch of stories today so let's get to it.

c: ^According to witnesses a new temple has appeared in the desert today.
^As if curated by some kind of Sand Gardener the temple has appeared, fully formed. The interior is reportedly intricate, labyrinthine, with many traps and treasures to discover.
^An explosion at a technology factory has injured around 100 workers.
^Reports say that those affected have been totally wiped of their memory and their capacity to feel emotion. They are dazed, confused, but eager to continue working.
^Somehow, none of the machinery in the factory, or the supervisors and executives have been affected by the explosion.
^Reports coming in from the Bleak District are saying there is a new sound coming from the mountains.
^Echoing and reverberating from caves, snow banks and stalactites, it has been described as "terrifyingly alien," and "like something out of a nightmare."
^We sent a correspondent to investigate, but we haven't heard back yet... Apart from a strange signal we recieved that could not be decoded, even by our best cryptographers.

g-0: ^I'm just being told that that's all the time we have for now. Something... um...
^Something bad has happened. We have to go.

static_god: ^The static here seems different to you.
^It seems as though it is trying to form an image... a message... a symbol?
^There is a warmth to the glow, a happy warmth.
^You see within the chaos, a beautiful happiness. Raw emotion and comfort. Between each of these pixels is an infinite space, an infinite chance to make things right.

^And suddenly you sink further down, deeper in, beyond the space between the pixels, and that happiness vanishes. You feel cold and alone, and everything is dark. There is absolutely nothing here, nothing to grab on to.
^Until you pull back out, and return to how things were.
^The static fizzes. You reach for the tuner again.
static_strange_signal: ^I don't know how to stop it, I can't stop thinking about them.
^Everytime I think I have a grip on things, they slip away again.
^I am sweating and I am having trouble breathing.
^I feel as though there is ice creeping up my spine.
^I just wish I could know that someone was listening.
BCE_CHANNEL: ^The static separates and disperses like a calming blizzard. You're not sure why, but you feel cold all of a sudden.
^A train makes its way across a windy mountain track, looping and curling, rising and falling. It pushes on through the snow, through the ice, it keeps going and going. It is somehow comforting.
^You feel the breeze, the rumbling and churning of the wheels. The cold stings your eyes.
CARTOONS: ^Two dogs in construction outfits stand infront of a hole they have dug. Inside the hole is a dinosaur skeleton. They talk to each other:

c: ^Probably should call the manager over? Right?
^Can you do it? I haven't taken my anxiety meds for a few days.

g-0: ^This sucks. What a shitty fucking day.

c: ^I guess we could like, rebury it? Cover it back up?
^You're right. Let's go get the manager.
^Alright gimme a moment I want a cig first.
^Sucks. Do you think we'll have to?
^Oh yeah sorry, I won't say medium-well either.
^I had a T-rex thigh once, was pretty good. Very dry though, not like those fresh bones you get.
^Yeah fuck it, no one will notice, right?
^Fucking not for ages man, I had to take out another payday loan last night.

INFOMERCIAL: ^It's buy buy buy all the time time time. 24 hour shopping from the comfort of your stained and greasy sofa.
^You're not going to believe the products we have lined up for you this everlasting night!
^Hundreds of special deals all for you. Just you... That's right, you're the only one here tonight. It's just you and me.

c: ^How many times do you find yourself struggling to reach the outer corners of your vast lawn? Find your hose catching on corners and getting tangled?
^Well with Infinity Hose, all these problems are gone.
^Infinity Hose is the first ever infinitely long hosepipe, and it can be all yours for only 100 tokens, and 100 tokens every month for 3 years.
^Water crops on the moon! Bring Infinity Hose camping with you for constant water supply! Build your own water park!
^Truly the possibilites are endless. Call now!
^And look at the ease with which this knife glides through this plutonium rod.
^Carved from the finest Mega Diamond money can buy, this knife. Oh my gosh this knife...
^I just love this knife so much.
^We all love The Oppressor. And not just because we have to.
^Now you can own your very own Mini Oppressor! With three small payment installments we will send you all you need to build your own gasmask-wearing tyrannical overlord.

^Fun for all the family and safe for children over the age of three! Fun construction for you budding engineers! Fun reminder for you budding protestors that a revolution will never ever happen and there's no point in even trying!

g-0: ^But that's not all, we have plenty more products to show  you!

c: ^Are the Monday blues getting you down? Feel yourself overcome by The Fear? Well no problem!
^For 100 tokens a week we will send you a daily supply of whatever booze you fancy! Whiskey, vodka, wine, beer, you name it, we'll deliver it.
^That's really all there is to it!
^This telephone only calls one number. What number? You'll have to buy to find out!

^We came upon this telephone late one autumn evening, exploring around the pylon forest. It was covered in moss and mildew and a small creature had made a home inside it, but we have cleaned it all out, ready for you!
^Buy now for this once in a lifetime opportunity!
^This dog is made entirely of recycled energy. It has no physical form and therefore needs no food or water.
^That's right! Unlimited unconditional love and it doesn't even need to be cared for!
^Get your ethereal dog companion today and cuddle with pure energy whenever you most need!

g-1: ^You didn't think that was it did you? We have so much more!

c: ^We all get sad from time to time. Sometimes the happy days seem so far away that it is hard to even remember them.
^But today, oh what a beautiful day it is today, we are offering you the chance to buy happiness!
^That's right! The ancient phrase is a lie. Money does equal happiness, and it can be sent directly to your home.
^To describe what you will find contained within will ruin the surprise, so just trust us. And send us your money.
^Love is a thing that can be bought, trust us. And for only 50000 tokens it can be yours!
^You will never be alone again. Why. Why did they leave me? God I am so lonely. I need help. You out there watching this, please, I need help desperately.
^I try to cry but nothing comes out. I haven't spoken to a real person in weeks. Why did they leave?
^I can't tell you how good an opporunity this is, I wish I could be the one buying!
^We are offering, for the first time, the ability to buy meaning for your life.
^Gone are those horrible nights wondering what your purpose is, what you were put here to do - we will reveal all!
^For a measly 50000 tokens, we will send you a Meaning pack, detailing all you could possibly want to know about the big questions.

SPOOKY_ASS_SHIT: ^A long black corridor with a light at the end. It seems as though it could go on forever.

c: ^The walls are matte and reflect no light, yet they are not fully black. They're almost black.
^You can barely hear anything at all apart from the sound of your own breathing.
^At least... you think that it is yours.
^Shadows move across the walls, you pick out some shapes.
^They appear somewhat humanoid, and... are those antlers?
^You can pick out some strange sounds... sobs, groans?
^There's a strange scuttling sound. It doesn't sound like anything you've heard before. Totally inhuman.

g-1: ^It is very cold and the tunnel is getting even darker.

c: ^You can barely see anything anymore. But at the end of the tunnel you notice something... something partially blocking the light.
^It is too far away to tell what it is, some kind of mound? Some kind of pile of something?
^You hear cries and screams, very loud now. Horrible noises.
^Your skin crawls and you feel uncomfortable. You want desperately for it to stop.

INTRO: ^You can't remember what time it is, but it feels late.
^You have just checked into your room at the Brownie Cove Hotel.
^Why was it that you were here again?

c: ^You think you remember reading that the hotel was a great place to relax, to get away from your troubles and reboot.
^Your employer booked you in for a conference about something, but you can't quite remember what.
^Now that you're here, it doesn't seem like the kinda place business gets done anyway.
^Come to think of it, you're not even sure how you got here.
^You can't see any sign of your suitcase and you have no wallet or phone on you. Strange.

g-0: ^The bed is lumpy and you can't sleep, but the TV is tempting...

DRIVING: ^An old car drives along a windy hillside road.
^It seems to be winter but there is no snow.
^The car passes an abandonned mine shaft.

c: ^The roof and one of the walls have collapses over time, but the tall stone chimney remains.
^It must've been hit by another car.
^They are blue and wear red backpacks.
^The leader holds a map and a compass.
^Bubbling and angry, eating its way through the ground.
^You wonder what kinds of fish live there, if any. And you wonder why it hasn't frozen.
^The trees are dense and block out all light, you can't see very far in.
^You wonder if anybody lives inside... how many people got lost and couldn't find their way out.

g-0: ^The car passes by an electricity pylon.

c: ^It is not connected to any wires, or to any other pylons. Perhaps a failed attempt at connecting more remote areas?
^Yet it still seems to be emitting some kind of energy.

g-1: ^You talk to the other person in the car.

c: ^You both wonder when the next petrol station will be.
^They tilt their chair back and fall asleep for a little while.
^You roll down the windows and sing along.
^Watercolour grass, dripping down the rocky outcrops.
^The hum of the car, the exhaust, the plumes of smoke from chimneys in the distance.

s: ^You keep driving on into the night.
^Something catches your eye and you turn to take a look.

DRAMA: ^I don't ever want to see you again.
^I don't care what you meant to do, this is what has happened.

g-0: ^I'm starting to wonder if I ever loved you.
g-1: ^It feels like you never loved me.
^Can you please be honest here like I just want to know the truth.

CURTAINS: ^From a distant viewpoint you see a window.
^It is night and their curtains are closed.
^You feel full of anticipation. Nervous energy.

c: ^The room is well lit and inside you can see somebody moving about.

s: ^They move to the left side of the room.

c: ^You wonder if there's anyone else in their house? If they are wanting some privacy.
^They pick some stuff up from the floor.
^You can't tell what it is. Probably clothes or something like that.
^You imagine the room to be quite messy.

s: ^They move to the right side of the room.

c: ^They read a book for a while. You can't tell what book it is.
^You wonder if they are going to sleep soon.
^They rummage around for something, but you can't see what.
^They turn around to face the room.
^You wonder what they are looking at.
^They stay facing the window and gaze outside.
^You are worried, for a moment, that they might be able to see you. But you know that they cannot.

CONCERT: ^Some kind of live concert. Somebody sits on a stage with a guitar.
^They are lit with a single spotlight.
^It is very intimate. You feel as though you are in the room with them.
^You can't hear any audience, but you are sure there must be.

g-0: ^It makes you think about the past.
^It makes you think about the future.
^It doesn't make you think about anything.
g-1: ^It seems to be an instrumental performance.
^You wish they would sing, but they don't.
^It reminds you of a song from a film you like.
^It reminds you of something you can't quite remember.
g-2: ^Eventually the song ends, but no one applauds.

ENDING: ^It seems that... the TV has run out of things for you tonight.
^The more you had, the worse it got, and now you have nothing.
^You wonder who else out there is watching the static right now.
^Will anyone ever see the same static that you do? Or is every moment totally unique?
^If you look closely, it's almost as if there are still more things out there, hidden between stations..
